prs.l: especially Southern and Midland US also

dt: {bc}a flat-bodied stringed instrument with a long fretted neck and usually six strings played with a pick or with the fingers

et: French {it}guitare{/it}, from Spanish {it}guitarra{/it}, from Arabic {it}qītār{/it}, from Greek {it}kithara{/it} cithara
shortdef: a flat-bodied stringed instrument with a long fretted neck and usually six strings played with a pick or with the fingers

dt: {bc}an imaginary guitar that one pretends to play

shortdef: an imaginary guitar that one pretends to play; also : the action of playing air guitar

dt: {bc}a usually electric stringed instrument having a long fretted neck and six to eight steel strings that are plucked while being pressed with a movable steel bar for a glissando effect

shortdef: a usually electric stringed instrument having a long fretted neck and six to eight steel strings that are plucked while being pressed with a movable steel bar for a glissando effect

dt: {bc}someone or something that retards or halts free movement and progress
{bc}a dramatic reduction in the size of a population (as of a species) that results in a decrease in genetic variation
{bc}a style of guitar playing in which glissando effects are produced by sliding an object (such as a knife blade or the neck of a {a_link|bottle}) along the strings

shortdef: someone or something that retards or halts free movement and progress

dt: {bc}a box-shaped musical instrument with legs that has usually 10 strings which can be altered in pitch by the use of pedals and which are plucked while being pressed with a movable steel bar

shortdef: a box-shaped musical instrument with legs that has usually 10 strings which can be altered in pitch by the use of pedals and which are plucked while being pressed with a movable steel bar —called also pedal steel guitar
